instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Got this one in with zero liquid damage looks clean as clean can be. Light on charger but no fan spin.

PP3V42: 3.42 volts
SMCBCACOK: 3.3
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>: 3.3
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0 volts at the fuse BUT I get 8.58 volts on the coil before the fuse (L7130)

No short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, fuse has continuity, continuity between fuse and coil present.

Checked <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7141</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7143</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7145</CAPACITOR> for being blown but they check out ok. 

Where do I check next?

Thanks.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Impossible to get 8.58V at L7130 but simultaneously 0V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Are you sure the fuse is not blown or gone into high resistance?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That’s what I’m saying!!! Checked for continuity at the fuse on both sides and got a beep. I literally don’t understand lmao it’a the weirdest thing!! Resistance to ground on PPBUS was like .8 so no short that I could find.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Resistance in Ohm on the fuse? Should be 0, if it detects any kind of resistance more then just touching your probes together it's dead

0.8Ohm to ground on PPBUS is definitely a short by the way. Inject voltage and find the source of the short.
Keep an eye on the temperature of the CPU because you can't inject more then 1.2V without having a chance of killing it when the CPU high MOSFET is shorting. If the CPU is not getting hot the short is somewhere else and you can increase the voltage further in case you reach the amparage limit

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ohhhh ok then yeah I think fuse is dead. Resistance when I measured it today was way more than 0. I’ll check that tomorrow and ohms I think was 240-300 ohms but I’ll remeasure that tomorrow to verify I kinda measured in a hurry. But yeah I’d bet fuse is dead in that case

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The fuse is dead for a reason usually a short on PPBUS.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok so fuse is dead. Removed short is on pin 2 so system side...is this dead CPU or should I inject voltage?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C7620</CAPACITOR> is split in half. Think I found problem will report back in a bit

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replaced the cap and the fuse and PPBUS is back and the machine turns on and boots into the OS! Mark as solved!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I do have a question tho as to why the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL> caps blow? I've had two this week with the same kind of issue where a big cap blows curious as to why? Bad charger, surge?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Nah, the Chinese chargers will kill the ISL and current sense resistors before killing caps on PPBUS. It is just plain random cap failure.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Gotcha that's weird. Well it's working good now so thanks for the help guys! Another one solved and working.
